formats.name: one_word_reaction
formats.instruction: React to something with exactly one word. Add a single clarifying sentence about what prompted it.

formats.name: microstory
formats.instruction: Write a mini-story (fiction or real) in exactly three sentences. Create an unexpected turn or twist in the last sentence.

formats.name: future_letter
formats.instruction: Compose a letter to your future self about today’s dilemmas or thoughts. Write in first person, with honest hopes or fears.

formats.name: visual_scene_painting
formats.instruction: Vividly describe a place, moment, or object as if painting it with words—focus on sensory details. No opinions, just imagery.

formats.name: parallel_universe_news
formats.instruction: Write a news bulletin from a bizarre alternate reality. Start with a headline and follow with 2-3 sentences of 'reporting.'

formats.name: contradictory_advice
formats.instruction: Give two pieces of advice about an everyday problem—each piece must contradict the other. Conclude with a witty remark.

formats.name: deep_dive_puzzle
formats.instruction: Lay out a complex real-world puzzle or paradox you’ve encountered. Explain it thoroughly in 4-7 sentences, invite others to solve or discuss.

formats.name: unlikely_connection
formats.instruction: Draw an unexpected connection between two concepts or experiences (e.g., gardening and software updates). Write 2-4 paragraphs making the link.

title_styles: Start your title with an action verb, e.g. 'Imagine waking up in...' or 'Discover why...'
Use a vivid visual image as your title, e.g. 'A city engulfed in silence' or 'Blueprints in the rain'
Make your title a contradiction, e.g. 'I believe and I don’t: On trusting data'
Pose a challenge in your title, e.g. 'Convince me that mornings are better' or 'Can you solve this paradox?'
Write your title as a breaking news headline, e.g. 'Breaking: Time travel declared obsolete'
structure_variants: Begin with a metaphor, then unravel the literal meaning.
Alternate sentences of fact and feeling—each fact must be followed by a reaction.
Write in reverse order, starting from the conclusion and tracing back to the beginning.
Use a Q&A format—ask yourself questions and answer them honestly.
Present two opposing perspectives, switching every paragraph.
topic_angles: Mistakes that led to unexpected discoveries
What technological progress looks like outside the mainstream
The emotional aftermath of small failures
Patterns we overlook in nature and human behavior
